title: Why do people have to make a big deal out of getting shot?

It's just a hole in your body.  You can still move around. You can still talk. It doesn't necessarily mean you're going to die right away.  So why the fuss? Is it because they're scared of dying? If so, then that's understandable. But if it's just because it hurts, then I think they're being overly sensitive.  I mean, there are plenty of things that hurt worse than getting shot. Like stubbing your toe or having a baby. So why is getting shot considered such a big deal?

title: Is it safe to leave a phone plugged in overnight?
self_text: Yes.  If you have an old charger that is not smart and has no protections, then yes. Otherwise the phone will stop charging when it reaches full charge. It does not matter if you leave it plugged in for hours after it is fully charged.   There are many safeguards in modern phones and chargers to prevent overcharging or overheating of the battery. However, it's still recommended to unplug your phone once it is fully charged because it can reduce the lifespan of the battery.  The battery is only rated for around 300-500 cycles before its performance degrades. The more often you cycle the battery, the faster it will degrade.  But honestly, it's probably not something worth worrying about unless you are planning on keeping your phone for 5+ years.

title: Can you get sick from touching a dirty dollar bill?
self_text: No, but they do carry bacteria and viruses that can be harmful to humans.  In fact, it’s estimated that up to 80% of the bills in circulation are contaminated with pathogens like E. coli and Salmonella.  These germs can survive on paper for days, so it’s important to wash your hands after handling cash.  Some people may also choose to disinfect their money with an alcohol-based hand sanitizer or wipe.   So, yes, you could potentially get sick from touching a dirty dollar bill if you don't take precautions.

title: Can you tell me what the difference is between a flashlight and an LED torch?
self_text: I am not from America, so please do not use American terms to explain it to me.  I just want to know what the difference is between them, if there even is one.

title: What does it mean to “take a knee?”
self_text: I am from the US and have seen many NBA players take a knee during the national anthem but don’t understand why or what it means.

title: Can I use a wet toothbrush to clean my skin?
self_text: Please explain why you would or wouldn’t recommend it.  I have oily acne prone skin and am looking for an effective way of washing the grime from my face without irritating it.   Is there any benefit to using a toothbrush on your face at all?

title: Is it okay to drink a glass of water after eating some fried food?
self_text: I had some fried chicken and my mom said that drinking water right away can cause indigestion so i waited for about an hour before drinking any fluids.   Is she right?

title: How can i make my dog stop eating laundry?
self_text: My dog has been eating clothes from the laundry hamper, is there anything I can do to help him with that habit?  I've tried a lot of different things but nothing seems to work so far.

title: How can I create a safe room to make my own content?
self_text: I'm trying to start making content but am not sure where or how to get started.   I've got some ideas on what I want to do, and have a few friends who are interested in being in it with me.  What should I be doing?

title: Why do people make a big deal out of having their own room?
self_text: I don't get it, my brother and I share a bedroom with two twin beds in the same room for years now and we both got along fine. It is not that bad at all, we have our own space to sleep but also can chat about stuff if we want to.  What are the benefits of having your own room instead of sharing?  I just don't see why it would be better than being able to hang out with someone you love every night before going to bed.

title: Why did they make a movie about the Titanic?
self_text: I’m not asking why it was such a tragedy, but like what was the point of making a movie about something so sad? Did anyone actually want to see that?  It just seems like an odd choice for entertainment.   I mean if you knew people died on that ship and there were children involved would you still want to watch the movie? Or even go on a cruise after that?   I can understand wanting to learn more about history and all but it's just strange to me.
